comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: It would be interesting to try to identify the 'gardeners' - the gentleman with the gray moustache  looks a little like Dr Bradfield ... but that's just a guess. Come on, this should test us!

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Good idea! I've replaced this with a larger version. I think you've picked JJC Bradfield. From this photo below we know that (third along) the woman is Mrs Davidson. AB

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: Well the gentleman either behind her or to her right may well be the Minister. Would they have involved people from the Town Hall - ie the Lord Mayor, Lady Mayoress, or the Town Clerk and his wife perhaps?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The article by Dr Bradfield in the SMH Supplement of 19/3/1932 (under "Lighting Arrangements") mentions - "The parklets are planted with silky oaks, red bottle brush, ficus hillii, with a Moreton Bay ash, a distinctive eucalypt in each for shade, also two rosemary bushes, planted by Rosemary Game and Rosemary Budge." trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28034317 I wonder if those are the Rosemarys? Rosemary Game was the wife of the NSW Governor, but I am not sure who Rosemary Budge was.

John

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Good question, I'll have a look.... Mrs Bradfield Miss Davidson

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: I think that Rosemary Game may have been the daughter of Sir Philip Game. Lady Game's first name was Gwendolen, and would not have been referred to in the paper without her title. Here's a bit about Rosemary Game: nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16775301

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:

comment.author: 59340782@N06
comment._content: As John Cowper has pointed out the Minister may be behind or next to his wife. The Minister was Mark Anthony Davidson, Secretary for Public Works in the 45th Lang Ministry from 4.11.1930-13.5.1932 (from list on NSW Parliamentary website). His wife's name was Gertrude from his Former Members biography.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: It doesn't take a lot of looking to determine that Rosemary Budge was the daughter of Sir Harry Budge. She is mentioned here trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/27986524?searchTerm=rose... and here trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/27986912?searchTerm=rose... and here trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17058078?searchTerm=rose... which mentions that she is a pal of Rosemary Game

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Rosemary Game and Rosemary Budge may have been a little younger than the women appearing in this image.... In 1934 it seems they were still at school: trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/17058078?searchTerm=rose... budge&searchLimits=l-decade=193 - AG

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5578135858/ I think we see the chap 2nd from the lhs in this other SRNSW pic. My guess is that he is W.H. (Bill) Lush, a supervising engineer with the NSW PWD.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: We gradually getting there, well done everyone!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/search.as... this pic appears to have been taken at another tree planting which took place on 29/8/1931...it puts a few more names to faces...but I'm not sure it helps us much here...apart from maybe firming up Lush as the chap 2nd from the lhs
